Fiscal policy (A way that the government steps into the economy to prevent excessive inflation or stimulate sluggish economy. The means are "government spending" and "taxes")

1. Expansionary policy
- When the economy is in a recession, the government increases government spending (reducing unemployment rate) and reduce taxes (stimulating consumption).

2. Contractionary policy
- When the economy is growing too fast, the government decreases government spending and increases taxes (reduces government and consumer consumption).

3. How effective?
- The U.S. government implemented expansionary policy in 2009, and it seemed like a failure. However, in the most of the European countries that exactly did the opposite (contractionary), the unemployment rate was raised and GDP got lowered. Economists conclude that the situation could've been worse if the U.S. did not implement the expansionary fiscal policy.

Main outtakes of this lesson
1) Recessionary gap - a situation wherein the real GDP is lower than potential GDP at the full employment level.
2) Inflationary gap - the amount by which the actual gross domestic product (GDP) exceeds potential full-employment GDP.
3) Macroeconomics - the study of the entire economy as a whole rather than individual markets.
4) Fiscal policy - the way a government adjusts its spending levels and tax rates to monitor and influence a nation's economy.
a. Expansionary Fiscal Policy - stimulates the economy during or anticipation of a business-cycle contraction.
b. Contractionary Fiscal Policy - enacted by a government to reduce the money supply and ultimately the spending in a country.
c. Classical theories assumed that the economy will fix itself in a long run, and that government intervention will, at best, lead to unintended consequences and, at worst, cause massive inflation and debt.
5) Deficit spending - the government spends more money than it collects in tax revenue.
a. Crowding out - where increased public sector spending replaces, or drives down, private sector spending.
b. Keynesian economists maintain that crowding out is only a problem if economy operates at full capacity, where all workers are employed and we're producing as much as we can.
6) Austerity - raising taxes and cutting government spending to reduce debt. In crisis of 2008 was main policy of EU, which led to worse results than deficit spending policy in US.
7) Multiplier effect - the initial increase in government spending of 100$ might turn out to be 175$ worth of actual spending in the economy.
a. When the economy is booming, multiplier is close to 1x.
b. When economy is in recession, the multiplier is around 2x.
c. Spending on infrastructure, and aid to state & local governments , also seems to have fairly high multiplier, about 1.5. But general cuts to payroll and income taxes seems to have a multiplier of about 1:. If the government cuts 100$ in taxes, the economy is going to grow by about 100$.

The sad thing is economics is no more a science than theoretical physics (e.g. without sufficient empirical evidence), sociology or even religion for one reason.

While humans are like computers in many ways, they aren't rigid. Thus an input likely will not give the desired output, although just as often, it will. Humans are also fickle in regards to both positive and negative stimuli and react quickly, often irrationally. This contaminates "theory" dramatically over time. If Keynes was actually right, bubbles wouldn't be shifting around the global economy from sector to sector; they'd simply be smaller overall and less painful when they burst. National debt / surplus also would ebb and flow as a counterbalance. This is obviously not the case and the only winners as this experiment has run its course (or losers in a lot of ways) are the lenders with productivity (and/or generational wealth) comfortably higher than their consumption in a twisted spiral of escalating interest payments which necessitates the ever lowering of interest rates which are systemically approaching negative and are an important signal or inflection point. This latter point also leads to the specter of cronyism which is a real thing, though, how truly endemic it is as an economic force which affects the system itself is debatable.

Freedom of subjectivity, has its own significant impact. Again, unless you have a despotic, mechanical and arguably tyrannical reign present you cannot control every detail of human behavior or opinion. Consequently, human perceptions rather than statistics drive most of the macro workings of their interaction together. Those perceptions are largely based on past events. If those are negative events, we are wired to reject them and not take them into consideration even if their passing would be beneficial in the longer term. Eventually the well intentioned coddling of human interaction will spiral out of control in a largely positive direction until enough people perceive that the medium, money, is without meaning any longer. Disenfranchisement takes hold and untold and unimaginable results present themselves.

That's the folly of intervention. It's not evil per-se, however it can be perceived as evil rather easily as historical examples of intervention have much more often than not lead to ultimate disasters after they run their course. It's just that the longer time frames involved leave room for the typical human to forget most of the details and causes of the events and focus more on the immediate situation thus going along with schemes that benefit them in the intermediate term.

My hope for the future is, once this system runs its course, crashes and burns with whatever calamity it brings; the information age will have connected enough people to the direct happenings that the folly of intervention will be less likely in the minds of the survivors. Either that or we somehow transcend the notion of scarcity and from then on the universe is our playground. Hope for the latter; prepare for the former. Couldn't hurt.

Reagan started with interest rates at 20% thanks to Carter, he was able to stimulate the economy multiple times with the Fed lowering interest rates throughout his administration.  Future administrations such as the Bush and Clinton administrations were also able to do this as well and power through recessions.  The problem that happened with the 2008 recession is the fact that interest rates hit near 0%, you could not lower interest rates anymore (i.e. -1% interest rate).  You can only super inject the economy for so long without having a net interest rate gain before you get a recession you can't get out of using those means.  This is why the Fed settled for a cash infusion of money i.e the bailout.  This does not have the same effect as lowering interest rates, it never will.  What people need to understand is, that we need to raise interest rates upwards, if we want to have another 20-30 year period of time where the economy can hum along.  If we don't we will be stuck in a perpetual recession with 2% growth and high unemployment.  This is what rock bottom looks like when it comes to Keynesian economics, near 0% interest rates and an exploding deficit.

The fallacy that government spending creates jobs is hardly older than the rebuttal to it.  While it is true that even a broken window helps the glazier to get some cash, the person who pays the glazier would otherwise have spent that money elsewhere.  This means that no new capital has been created.  Only the direction of spending has been altered.  The same principle applies on a national scale; as the money used to build a road or a bridge isn't conjured out of thin air, but is simply a redirection of where that money would have been spent.  So not only have you not created jobs, but you may well have destroyed some.  All this before we get to the problem of national debt and inflation.

Way back in the 1970s, when I was studying 3-Unit Economics in High School, my Cousin (the University Student) lent me a Textbook...; wherein I read of the "BALANCED BUDGET MULTIPLIER THEOREM..."

The idea was that if ever a Government could balance their Budget 2 Years in a Row, but the 2nd Year's Budget was larger in real terms than the 1st one, then due to the particular Sectors of Society in which the Government Spends Money ; therefore there "Shall Be" (Hypothetically, so the Theorem goes) a measurable extra Multiplier-Effect proportional to, BUT ADDITIONAL TO, the Economy's "Background Multiplier Effect"...

When I read it, at 17, I thought it was "The Answer" to the Classical/Keynsian Dichotomy...

But that Chapter concluded by mentioning that the reason the BBM Theorem was STILL a Theorem rather than a THEORY, is that it has never ever been Tested...; owing to the salient point that within Recorded History NO GOVERNMENT HAS EVER BALANCED IT'S BUDGET 2 Years in a Row...

Through the 19th century of US history there were numerous recessions/depressions in the United States, often called panics about every 15-20 years. These were pretty bad, but large sections of the US population got off without too much difficulty as they were small farmers who owned their own plots of land. Even if said farmers took a hit, they still could get the basics on their own (Food, Candles, Clothes). But as time more and more of the population moved into the cities and more people paid rent, bought their food and similar and were more invested in the cash economy on a day to day basis and the US grew in size and international prominance while the world economy became more interconnected thanks to radio and undersea telegaraph lines, especially after WWI. As such when another big recession hit (as it did in 1929), it effected every industrial world. So measures were put into place to prevent this sort of thing from happening again, financial regulation and stimulus. For nearly eighty years we have not seen a recession on the scale of that of the 1930s.

The comparison to the US and EU policy did not take into account the massively different interest rates those countries where paying for debt that the effect that expansionary spending would have on the  interest rates of new debt. Greece is the most extreme, with the interest of 10 year loans getting to over 40%. Meaning if had an expansionary spending where government debt spending was 10% of it's GDP, after 3 years interest on ONLY the new loans would be 12% of GDP. No one believes that Greece would ever get the growth that would allow them to pay that debt, so the debt rate only goes higher. US debt interest on the other hand was only ~2%, so the cost of expansionary spending was very low for the US. You can't cover everything, but that was a big key when comparing US and EU spending. Also, the main reason the US did not see much growth in spite of spend $800B, is that when government debt went from 70% of GDP to 100% of GDP, private sector debt when to ~260% of GDP to 200% GDP, causing a net loss of 30% of total debt over as a percent of GDP over ~6 years.
